summary: This is a Department of Justice Office of the Inspector General (OIG) memorandum providing a status update on the Federal Bureau of Prisons' (BOP) response to eight recommendations from a June 2023 OIG report concerning the custody, care, and supervision of Jeffrey Epstein at the Metropolitan Correctional Center. The memo details BOP's reported actions and the OIG's analysis, keeping all recommendations as 'Resolved' pending further review of finalized policies.

persons.name: Jeffrey Epstein
persons.context: The deceased inmate whose custody and death at the Metropolitan Correctional Center prompted the original OIG investigation and the subsequent recommendations to the BOP.

events.title: OIG Final Report Release
events.description: The Office of the Inspector General issued its final report on the investigation and review of the BOP's custody, care, and supervision of Jeffrey Epstein at the Metropolitan Correctional Center.

events.title: BOP Status Update Submission
events.description: The Federal Bureau of Prisons provided a status update to the OIG in response to the eight recommendations from the June 2023 report.

locations: Metropolitan Correctional Center, New York, New York
keyFacts: The OIG's June 2023 report made eight specific recommendations to the BOP to address failures related to the supervision of Jeffrey Epstein, who died in custody.
All eight recommendations remain 'Resolved' as of this April 2024 update, meaning the BOP has reported responsive actions but the OIG has not yet closed them pending review of finalized policies.

Key recommendations focus on procedures for assigning cellmates after suicide watch, ensuring high-risk inmates have cellmates, improving inmate whereabouts accounting, clarifying Lieutenant round duties, addressing staffing shortages, evaluating cell search procedures, and enhancing security camera policies.

The BOP is drafting or updating multiple policy manuals (Correctional Services Procedures Manual, Facilities Operations Manual) and developing an automated staffing tool in response to the recommendations.
The document reveals systemic issues within BOP procedures for suicide prevention, inmate monitoring, and staffing that were highlighted by the Epstein case.
